image.altText: Jeune ridden by Wayne Harris wins the 1994 Melbourne Cup

props.synopsis: The jockey who rode 35 group one winners over a storied career wrote his name into Australian sporting folklore as a Melbourne Cup winner in 1994.

title.children: Three decades on from his greatest ride, Wayne Harris typifies the spirit of the Melbourne Cup

image.altText: Racegoers walk through the gates at Flemington on Melbourne Cup day

props.synopsis: Anti-racing protesters and animal rights advocates are optimistic the tide has permanently turned against horse racing and fewer young people are watching the Melbourne Cup. But with the #NupToTheCup movement appearing to lose steam, celebrities and influencers are back at Flemington in force.

title.children: Melbourne Cup day raises complicated feelings about horse racing for many Australians

image.altText: A tram on a Melbourne street.

props.synopsis: Five girls wearing Jewish school uniforms are allegedly abused by men on a tram in Melbourne's south-east.

title.children: Victorian police investigate alleged anti-Semitic abuse targeted at Melbourne high school students

image.altText: Two smiling women holding up a completed jigsaw puzzle in what appears to be a media room.

props.synopsis: After taking up the hobby during the coronavirus lockdowns, a Victorian doctor has taken her place among competitive puzzling's world elite with a strong showing at the World Championships in Spain.

title.children: Young Victorian doctor vies for title of world's best puzzler

image.altText: Branding for the betting company 'bet365' on an electronic billboard on part of a stadium at an AFL game.

props.synopsis: Hoping to win over concerned Labor backbenchers, the federal government considers bans on in-stadium electronic gambling ads and betting company logos on sports jerseys.

title.children: Government considering in-stadium gambling ad ban to win over Labor backbenchers

image.altText: A man stands in a room that was destroyed in a fire with black soot on the walls and burnt furniture

props.synopsis: Sam and Miral lost their office in the recent spate of arson attacks across Adelaide, which police say are part of a war being waged by interstate organised crime syndicates trying to control the state's illicit tobacco trade.

title.children: 'We are trying to survive': Tobacco wars hit innocent business owners

image.altText: e-scooters in Darwin

props.synopsis: As cities around the world ban or restrict shareable e-scooters over safety concerns, some governments in Australia are looking to decriminalise the use of private personal mobility devices in public.

title.children: Australia's e-scooter 'Wild West' prompts calls for nationally consistent rules

image.altText: An assembled 3D printed gun. Parts have been printed in blue, orange and black filament.

props.synopsis: A record number of illegal 3D-printed guns have been seized across every state and territory. Police warn these firearms are lethal and those found with the blueprints to make them could face years in jail.

title.children: 3D-printed guns look like children's toys. They're lethal and on the rise

props.synopsis: Australia's former top diplomat says US ambassador Kevin Rudd can work with Donald Trump, and he doesn't believe AUKUS and trade deals are under threat.

title.children: Kevin Rudd can work with Trump, preserve ties: ex-top diplomat

image.altText: Ruby Lenora casts her in-person vote on her 73rd birthday

props.synopsis: US presidential elections are a peculiar beast. If you want to track who's winning the race for the White House in real time, you have to know when results from key states come in.

title.children: When do I need to check in on the US presidential election results?

image.altText: A university graduate wearing a gown and cap is seen outside Parliament House in Canberra

props.synopsis: The federal government hopes to announce a promise to change university course fees before the year's end, with its one-off cuts to existing graduate debts considered an "interim" measure.

title.children: One-off HECS debt cut a placeholder as government looks to change university course fees

image.altText: A purple lightning strike fills the sky.

props.synopsis: Victorian authorities brace for difficult fire conditions with high temperatures and storms with dry lightning forecast this week.

title.children: Dry thunderstorms could spark hundreds of fires in Victoria this week, weather bureau warns

image.altText: A jockey urges his horse to the line in the Melbourne Cup as another horse runs on in the background.

props.synopsis: The Melbourne Cup has changed greatly in 30 years, but some things remain the same. Just ask three-time cup-winning jockey Kerrin McEvoy.

title.children: 'It's not irrevocable, but it is a real disadvantage': The evolving tactics of winning the Melbourne Cup

image.altText: Flaudulent election material.

props.synopsis: "Ridiculous" use of AI and fake social media accounts interfere with local council elections in Victoria.

title.children: Fake Facebook accounts spread disinformation during local government elections

image.altText: Glass of orange juice with oranges

props.synopsis: There's a good reason the price of orange juice has risen and supermarkets are not to blame.

title.children: Orange juice price-hike hard on shoppers' pockets but good news for Aussie farmers

image.altText: Leigh Haussen practices his bounce before and AFL match in the centre of the field

props.synopsis: AFL field umpire Leigh Haussen will not be eligible to officiate the first round of the 2025 AFL season after he dressed as Osama bin Laden at an end of season event.

title.children: AFL umpire banned for 'inappropriate' costume at end of season event

image.altText: A black ROG Phone 5 Android mobile phone screen featuring a round, purple star image

props.synopsis: Australians using 4G- or 5G-compatible phones say telcos and retailers are not doing enough to protect them from being left without critical access to mobile networks.

title.children: Australia's 3G network has shut down, so why are 4G and 5G users being cut off?

image.altText: Quincy Jones smiling, wearing sunglasses.

props.synopsis: Jones's historic career ranged from producing Michael Jackson's record-setting Thriller to prize-winning film and television scores and collaborations with Frank Sinatra and Ray Charles.

title.children: Quincy Jones, music titan who worked with everyone from Frank Sinatra to Michael Jackson, dies at 91

image.altText: A composite image showing Donald Trump looking the right and Kamala Harris looking to the left.

props.synopsis: America's economy is booming but everyday life is much more expensive than it was four years ago — and that is the one question that's leading some voters to vote for Donald Trump.

title.children: The rising problem fuelling support for Trump days ahead of the US election

image.altText: Kamala Harris smiles and holds arms in air

props.synopsis: The question about whether a woman can become the president of the United States has been asked time and again. Yet in other parts of the world, the question has already been answered with an emphatic "yes".

title.children: From the Pacific to South America: Meet the women beating misogyny and prejudice to lead their nation

image.altText: William Tyrrell smiling holding a cup with Lady Justice behind

props.synopsis: Any evidence police have gathered against William Tyrrell's foster mother will finally be presented to a coroner as the inquest into the toddler's disappearance resumes this week.

title.children: William Tyrrell inquest resumes with new details of police theory about involvement of former foster mother

image.altText: A girl looks towards the camera while sitting on her father's lap.

props.synopsis: It took 10-year-old Ashley Clifford's parents a decade of bouncing from specialist to specialist for their daughter to be diagnosed with Beck-Fahrner syndrome, and they're confident more families are in the same limbo they once were.

title.children: 10-year-old Ashley is one of only 30 people in the world known to have Beck-Fahrner syndrome

image.altText: Six people stand behind one man who is speaking at a podium in a suit

props.synopsis: A highly vaunted push to "rapidly" develop disruptive military technologies into the Australian Defence Force is facing uncertainty, with local companies saying an initial project has been "cancelled".

title.children: Australian companies furious after advanced defence technology project 'cancelled'

image.altText: gaza strike

props.synopsis: The Israeli military (IDF) says it has killed a commander in the Hezbollah Radwan force's anti-tank missile unit.

title.children: Israel military says it killed a commander in Hezbollah's Radwan force, as air strikes kill 10 people in Gaza

image.altText: Eric Idle, a man in his 80s, wears a tuxedo on a red carpet, with a blue media wall behind him.

props.synopsis: Eric Idle, one-sixth of legendary comedy group Monty Python, brings his new live show, Always Look on the Bright Side of Life, Live!, to Australia this month.

title.children: Eric Idle is proud to be behind one of England's top funeral songs. But it came from desperation

image.altText: Jaala Hinchcliffe giving evidence at Senate estimates.

props.synopsis: The acting boss of the Department of Parliamentary Services says she is unable to say when the secretary, who is currently on extended paid leave, would return to work.

title.children: Senators grill acting Parliament House boss over secretary's absence, lucrative payment and corruption raids

image.altText: The wreckage of a crumpled bus at the bottom of a gorge in India. The bus is crushed.

props.synopsis: The bus was carrying around 60 passengers from Garhwal in the Himalayas.

title.children: Bus crash in India kills 36 people on dangerous Himalayan mountain route

image.altText: Roads ripped under flood waters.

props.synopsis: The army sent a total of about 7,500 soldiers over the weekend to help distribute food and water, clean up streets and guard against looters.

title.children: Spain deploys more troops to flood zone as authorities warn of landslides and more flooding

image.altText: pat cummins

props.synopsis: Australia gets its summer of cricket off to a winning start, claiming a victory in the first of a three-game ODI series against Pakistan at the MCG.

title.children: Australia claim victory over Pakistan at MCG

image.altText: Maya Rudolph and Kamala Harris

props.synopsis: For 50 years, Saturday Night Live has been at the forefront of US political satire. Here are some of the politicians, presidents and White House hopefuls who have made an appearance.

title.children: Kamala Harris joins line of US politicians appearing on Saturday Night Live

image.altText: Amrita facing away from the camera

props.synopsis: When Amrita moved to Australia with her husband he was "very gentle", but soon after his family was treating her like a servant. New laws are set to finally recognise dowry abuse as a form of domestic violence to help those in similar situations.

title.children: 'Daylight robbery' of dowry abuse leaving women stranded, but new laws offer hope

image.altText: a man smiling sitting next to a woman wearing a wedding dress

props.synopsis: Jordan Fineanganofo, 23, pleaded not guilty to six charges including the murder of paramedic Steven Tougher outside a Campbelltown McDonald's in April 2023. Mr Tougher's family wept in a Sydney courtroom while hearing graphic details of the stabbing attack.

title.children: Man charged with murder of paramedic could be found not criminally responsible, court hears

image.altText: A pod of pilot whales in the water with a medium-sized cruise vessel alongside them.

props.synopsis: Riley Grining was skippering a cruise around Tasmania's Macquarie Harbour on Sunday when he received a call to help stop a pod of pilot whales from stranding themselves on a beach.

title.children: 'It could have been way worse': Boats help shepherd whale pod out of Hells Gates to avoid mass stranding
